captions.text:
l couldn't sleep.
Nor l. My aunt....
Yes. She was here.

How can l ever make amends
for such behavior?

After what you have
done for Lydia,
and l suspect for Jane also...

it is l who should be
making amends.

You must know.
Surely you must know
it was all for you.

You are too generous
to trifle with me.

l believe you spoke
with my aunt last night...

and it has
taught me to hope...

as l had scarcely
allowed myself before.

lf your feelings are still
what they were last April...
tell me so at once.

My affections and wishes
have not changed...

but one word from you
will silence me forever.

lf, however,
your feelings have changed...

l would have to tell you,
you have bewitched me,
body and soul...

and l love.... l love....
l love you.

l never wish to be
parted from you
from this day on.
Well, then.
Your hands are cold.
[birds chirping]

title: Bewitched - Pride & Prejudice (10/10) Movie CLIP (2005) HD

comments.text:
My mom took me to watch this when it first came out in 2005 but I was a 
fifth grader and didn't really understand what was going on but I grew up 
thinking I didn't like it. Then at the end of last year (2014), I decided 
to rewatch it and OH MY GOD, it's amazing! I can see why my 11 year old 
self didn't get it but now... Now that I can understand the older English 
style of speaking and what's actually being said, I can't get enough of 
this movie.﻿

comments.text:
He needed three attempts at saying "I love you". The final attempt was his 
best with the choke in the throat. Lizzy's best moment was "Your hands are 
cold" which signaled the putting of his forehead on hers and then raising 
his right hand to stroke her face.

In the first proposal, it was the final bit with the tilt of his head and 
her lowering of her head as if to position themselves for a kiss that did 
not come. Despite the verbal acrimony, the strong attraction was all there.﻿

comments.text:
The thing I find really interesting but only just noticed is the importance 
of Lizzie kissing Darcy's hand. it's a surprisingly subversive  gesture for 
a period piece like this. You'd generally expect a gesture like that to 
come from the man  in a period setting like this, or even in a modern 
setting. Speaks volumes about Lizzie's character, this little gesture. ﻿

comments.author: Erika Lobo

comments.text:
As a girl looking at all of these, "There aren't men like this" posts... I 
can't help be reminded how many of them are likely written by girls who 
have had men they have friend-zoned because they were not what they were 
looking for. Usually it's because they want a "bad boy" or they want 
someone who is already successful and rich. Not every man can be a rich 
lord of the manner, ladies.

If you put your value in kindness and sincerity - you will be rewarded.

I'm fortunate enough to have a fiance whose relationship was fostered from 
a friendship and compassion. Neither of us was really looking, but he 
realized one day that I was the one he couldn't live without and after 
being friends in high-school, time apart, and 2 years after reconnecting( 
where I was terrified to let him in close because he wasn't what I thought 
I needed) I finally agreed to go on a date. That was the best risk I ever 
took, as he has been my most valuable asset. But it was my witt, honesty, 
and sharp mind that won him - not beauty.

So stop friendzoning men because they're "boring" or too nice. That is 
where the good men have gone, and you only have yourselves to blame in most 
instances. (not all).﻿
comments.author: GunmetalRaven

comments.text:
+GunmetalRaven The truth is tight but not so much if you analyze some 
aspects.

In general I have really nice relationships with some women, BUT I have 
noticed problem when I try to create something more deep, they care too 
much to social power and safety which are things that leads 1 couple on 2 
to the divorce, this is a real statisic :( Furthermore people rely on bad 
place (discos are a cancer of our society) to create relationship because 
they follow the mass which don't help create good relationship. These are 
just examples to sustain my point of views.

As you can see social power and safety are poor values, but are really 
powerful in our society context, until they last. One day they wake up and 
they say "I thought was a different person...". If these seem too much 
generic because some people don't follow these bad values, the last one is 
the most important.

A lot of women, and also men, have problem to communicate, they are really 
close when they should embrace the new (unfortunately here if women are 
strange, the problem are also men). Often people prefer to complete their 
lacks with another person rather than working hard on themselves.

I'm not a misogynistic and pompous individual because I've left women do 
what they want. I was really shy and weak until I realized that they asked 
for either a strong and emphatic presence. Then I started to build the 
stronger version of myself, several results and satisfactions. I'm ready to 
embrace the new and the best...but if you look at previous paragraphs 
something is not working "outside". Then my remark ;) ...

So, you undestand that in some way I was shy (...wouldn't be openly 
speaking about himself with such bravado...), in some way I don't 
particularly like society (sociophobic?), in some way I built up a 
"stronghold" around me (sheltered?), and at the really beginning I pointed 
the finger only towards outside or following wrong attitude/sacrifice 
(martyr?).

Both Darcy and Elisabeth are strong people that are different from the 
mass. In fact Elisabeth isn't sure about wedding and men stuff as are 
usually considered. In a sad, but even really funny, context they are the 
only couple that can will be happy but their happiness starts from 
themselves, even though is not totally satisfied.
comments.author: Enrico C.

comments.text:
+Enrico C.
I can see that you're a misogynistic and pompous individual who is very 
quick to paint all women as fickle creatures who "don't know" what they 
want by your manner alone. How you perceive and comment on others, 
particularly an entire gender is quite telling.

Have you considered that may be the reason you keep running into women like 
that is because there's something about you that is drawn to women who 
apparently just aren't really that into you but are drawn to you for other 
reasons? What about you is attracted / attracting those type of women? It's 
something about either where you're seeking female company or where you 
choose to "water". 

You seem to think that rational women are the exception, or you don't have 
enough experience with actual women to really know better. I'm not honestly 
quite sure which is true. But you're mannerism behind the "anonymous" 
username does tell me quite a bit.

I only deal with you because I realize you don't speak for all men. You're 
just one individual with a very warped view of the other half of the human 
species.

The original post itself dealt with the fact that there are women who are 
very knowingly keeping "good" men on the backburner and taking advantage of 
them in favor of following their biological drives towards more classically 
alpha male types that they are more physically attracted to. I.E. Always 
drawn to the bad boy types even though they have a male friend who loves 
them dearly and would treat them better. Very often it takes either gender 
getting older and meeting new people before they come to appreciate things 
like that. Guys are just more socially supported in their "playing the 
field".

Then again I also support guys who are in love with a girl who doesn't 
appreciate them moving on and finding someone who will. It's a two way 
street. Granted people settle for the love they think they deserve.
comments.author: GunmetalRaven

comments.text:
+adamcrookedsmile I think that this is a lie :) She tried just a little bit 
to understand what kind of man I am, making a mistake of course, because 
she cannot know who I am just through a couple of messages. I talked in 
general because the first point of the discussion was covered in general 
and it wasn't definitely about whether I am a darcy-like men or not (which 
is not a problem for me, our dear Darcy is just a version of what some 
women want).

Pointing the finger towards someone is easier than analyzing the whole 
scenario, though.
comments.author: Enrico C.

comments.text:
+Enrico C.
it's interesting to note how you're talking about *women in general* but 
Gunmetal tries repeatedly to make this about *you* and whether or not *you* 
are Darcy-like, instead of discusing if *men in general* are Darcy-like.

Why do you think that is?
comments.author: adamcrookedsmile

comments.text:
Regarding the first part...you are talking again about biology. Fear to be 
alone, attraction from fascination and fast adventures are basic instinct, 
that's why people follow them rather than relying on values. But I repeat, 
it's a shame because we are better than this. So, lack of values, weakness 
and lazyness.

"Also not all women act differently than what they say..."
The second paragraph doesn't make sense to me, because women will never 
admit this fact. It's pretty normal, though. Lack of values and weakness 
can support this. Hope to be contradicted by REAL fact, one day. There are 
obviously exceptions, but the statististic go toward this line.

No. I'm not thinking that you are young and ingenue. I never said that. If 
I'm talking to you and I gave you a like it's because I think the opposite.

You don't have information about judging me as Darcy. So you have to 
believe me or not and don't be rigid, Darcy it's just a kind of man, there 
are always shades of grey on characters. Darcy is a sort of guideline.
My remark was also a provocation and was: Darcy is more common than you 
would think, without considering every single aspect that it's not very 
important at all.
As I said, now I'm less "Darcy" than in the past, or at least your vison of 
him, but I don't see a contradiciton between talking clearly about myself 
and being a Darcy-like man. Facts counts more than qualifying, but we are 
also in 2000s so, again, don't be rigid.
Peacock? You are exaggerating...I only said that I studied, observed and 
then judged. Peacocking is definitely more "rude".
comments.author: Enrico C.

comments.text:
+Enrico C.
Let me give you an example regarding the :

"Most people don't know what they want or actually need in a relationship."

I'd say that of the majority of people that I know, they are in 
relationships simply based because they are afraid of being alone or 
because it's what's expected with them. Their dating partners are generally 
not a result of them finding someone who shares a common interest with whom 
they've first fostered a friendship with depth. They rely on the internet, 
friends setting them up, clubs, and hook up apps. The other extreme is that 
they are always "attracted" to the wrong type of person. I.E. The guy who 
is so overly invested in appearance that he doesn't pay attention to 
personality - hence the "pretty, crazy bitch" trope. Women can do the same 
thing. It takes time to cultivate a relationship with more depth, and let's 
be honest - people are impatient.

Also not all women act differently than what they say. If you're running 
into this a lot, it might because they're just not that into you or they're 
realizing you're not a good fit with them and thus thinking about keeping 
their options open for something better. Guys do this too.

You'd think I was some simpering little 18 year old by the way you reply to 
me, not a full grown woman with a few years of psychology, anthropology, 
and life experience under my belt.

I state you're not a Mr. Darcy because Mr. Darcy wouldn't be openly 
speaking about himself with such bravado. He seemed more the "my acts" 
speak for me type. Considering that the books are set in the late Regency 
Era, it was considered tremendously rude for a man to speak of himself at 
length, which is why Elizabeth likely relied upon gossip to learn as much 
about him. Not to mention Darcy was a bit sheltered, sociophobic, and had a 
bit of a martyr complex.

You, sir, do not seem to share those traits. You're a peacock from your 
present display.
comments.author: GunmetalRaven

comments.text:
+GunmetalRaven but I'm not criticising you, my comment was a remark. Yes, 
some women are more sensible to your point of view of course and, yes 
biology matters and you didn't mention about this last fact, so maybe your 
remark was incomplete (and I understood very well your message). I would 
prefer creating a relationship based on instincts rather than romantic, or 
whatever, thoughts. Even though it's a shame.

"I will agree most people ( not just women ) know what they want or 
actually need in a relationship"...
Wrong, people don't know what they want, especially women that are more 
emotional. That's why they act differently from what they say. Did you 
remember biology?

"you're not "Darcy" at all"
you simply don't know :) then don't judge, people have the presumption to 
know too much. Study, observe and then judge, as I do. Then start to judge. 
If I made that remark It's because I "studied" women. I love women but they 
are very (very) contradictory. That was my remark. So, don't try to teach 
me what values are important, because I already have values, and they are 
good.
comments.author: Enrico C.

comments.text: +adamcrookedsmile I already know
comments.author: Enrico C.

comments.text:
+Enrico C. You do realize that my comment was meant towards that very 
concept? Not all women are like that fortunately. There's biology behind 
some of it, but then again if having to assert how "wonderful" and claim to 
be like Mr. Darcy, chances are you've missed the entire point of my initial 
remark as well as showing that you're not "Darcy" at all.

But that noted, I will agree most people ( not just women ) know what they 
want or actually need in a relationship. It's human nature to always want 
"better", especially if you're trust has been betrayed in the past.

Granted the whole point of the book was that Elizabeth was too busy paying 
attention to gossip and Darcy was too stuck up his own ass.
comments.author: GunmetalRaven

comments.text:
+Enrico C.
you're better off watching what women do than listening to what they say. 
Men too, for that matter.
comments.author: adamcrookedsmile

comments.text:
+GunmetalRaven I'm a man and I would say that women actually do exactly the

It's that simple, that's why men as Darcy are impossible to find today. I'm

Romanticism doesn't pay, being a bad boy or whatever does. Make peace with

comments.author: Enrico C.

comments.text:

comments.text:
+Ahilea Wind you don't know me so stop pretending that you do, it's really 
fake of you.

All I said was that I think men should stop "being friends" with women 
they're interested in but who don't want them.

The fact that a hypothetical woman decides to go out with a man who doesn't 
treat her as well should teach the friendzoned dude that treating her well *will 
never make her fall in love with him*. It doesn't teach him that because 
he's either stupid, naive, infatuated or all three at the same time.

It's of course a good point that a woman who goes out with such a man is 
material for neither relationships, friendships or "friendships".

comments.text:
So true. I can't date a guy I can't be good friends with anyway. So a lot

comments.author: Charne Jones

comments.text:
I have no idea, why people claim that Colin Firth is the best Mr Darcy. I 
find both of them good, each one in his own way. I think it was a very good 
idea to not copy Firth and emphasize a different part of Darcy, more 
brooding, more introvert ... more vulnerable. I melted instantly in the 
first scene with this Mr Darcy. And in this scene here ... oh the 
culmination of sensitivity that could be anticipated right from the 
beginning! All the deep, brooding emotions, that could be sensed right from 
the first minute and were held back for so long, finally reveal themselves 
and break out openly, still in that shy way. Adorable! I just love this 
movie!!!﻿
comments.author: Suedetussy

comments.text: that voice... <3﻿
comments.author: Starflower B

comments.text:
Call me a brainless potz or just pathetic, because I am, but I do believe 
this is the most beautiful, THE most romantic movie scene ever! Though I 
would prefer to see him wearing jeans and tee,  accessorized with pilot 
sunglasses and huge headphones over his head, saying: "Yo, what's up 
biatch?" lol﻿
comments.author: Marie Osipova

comments.text: Please. All men and boys in this generation. Learn from Mr. Darcy please.﻿
comments.author: Paulina Kovalenko

comments.text:
Not all fans of the book need the closest adaptation of the story to think 
of it as the best. The BBC version had the advantage of more hours to tell 
the story as well. However, this version more than made up for it by little 
nuances, like close ups on Darcy's hand each time he has a close encounter 
with Lizzy or the background stories happening at the Netherfield ball 
while Lizzy was walking around. I love this version because I thought the 
casting was really good, the story was alive and the passion between Lizzy 
and Darcy, even when they were verbally sparring, smoked the screen. 

I love this movie for what it is and do not wish for what it could be.﻿
comments.author: Casey K

comments.text: This music is truly spellbinding ﻿

comments.text:
It is very rare to see love like this during this time of heavy based sex 
crazed minds. I've always wanted a relationship like this one, or that 
makes me feel that warm feeling inside every time I'm with him. This scene 
is by far the best I have ever had the pleasure of witnessing on the sliver 
screen. <3 Kudos to Jane Austin's Pride and Prejudice, my all time favorite 
fictional romance book/movie! :D﻿

comments.text:
I absolutely love this movie that's become a favourite. The music and 
visual beauty are pure poetry, the cast almost perfect, but the chemistry 
and repressed passions and emotions are simply amazing and a joy to watch, 
especially between Lizzie and Mr Darcy. A great story and the best version 
so far. ﻿

comments.author: emmarose7172

comments.text:
What I loved about this story was there was no sex scene, there was no 
passion. It was romantic, but it wasn't passionate love. It was warmth, it 
was intimate, and it was between 2 people who actually care about each 
other. Maybe I'm just too much of a bookworm when I say I really do believe 
this kind of love exists, and that soon or later this will happen to me 
too.﻿

There is no sex scene because it is based on a novel which is over 200

Thank you! I was wondering all the time, why I loved this movie so much, 
although I'm not into romantic movies. Because this is the real stuff, not 
like the movies with Jennifer Aniston. This is the truest sense of romance,

and intimate, and the romantic tension between was felt quite from the 
first moment, Darcy noticed Lizzy.

comments.text: 1:58-2:00 and up, the feels!﻿
comments.author: VeryBeowulf

comments.text:
Just watched this movie for the first time last weekend and am now obsessed 
with this couple's love story! It inspired me to read the book (in one 
day..lol) and I thought with the short amount of time they had, they did 
the book justice.

To me, the act of Lizzy taking and kissing Darcy's hand symbolizes her 
acceptance of his hand in marriage. This balances the rain scene when she 
first rejected him.

And that slight smile on Lizzy's face when Darcy said "My affections and 
wishes have not changed"..=priceless!

This and the Pemberley visit scenes are my favourite.﻿

anyone knows the name of the song at the beginning when hes walking up to

comments.author: thepurplepiano21

comments.text:
It IS "Your Hands Are Cold," but, if you are wondering about specifics, 
that song is a combination of "Liz on Top of the World" and another song in 
the soundtrack (I think "Mrs. Darcy"). The part where he is walking is the 
entire song of "Liz on Top of the World." 
It's been a while since you asked this, but I thought I would let you know 
in case you were on the hunt for sheet music or something. There is not 
piano sheet music for this song but there is for the walking part, "Liz on 
Top of the World." 👍
comments.author: Brianna Riggio

comments.text:
It's not a *song* as such. It's just part of the music soundtrack for this 
movie. I think it may be character driven ie specific to scenes with Mr 
Darcy or Elizabeth only but it was created as part of the score by the 
music director. Definitely one of the most poetic and romantic movie scores 
I've heard. Love it!

comments.author: zynab1234

comments.text:
+zynab1234
Be sure you watch the British one with Richard Armitrage, which is a great 
version of a 19th century novel by Elizabeth Gaskell.  (There's another 
movie with the same name, about the American Civil War, that is just 
awful.)  RA plays a darkly handsome, reserved hero who melts his own heart, 
his lady love's and all his viewers' at the end.  If you love P&P, you'll 
love this movie too. (As an added bonus, it was Brendan Coyle's performance 
in North and South that got him the role of Bates in Downton Abbey.)
comments.author: Miz J
